data.question: Meetings - Open Attendance
data.description: Monthly board meetings are open for member-owners to attend without asking permission and this is clearly stated in the bylaws.

data.question: Meetings - Speaking Permission
data.description: Member-owners may speak at the monthly meetings without requesting permission in advance.

data.question: Meetings - Calendar/Agenda
data.description: Board meeting dates, times, location, and agenda are available online.

data.question: Meetings - Minutes
data.description: Detailed meeting minutes for each board meeting are available on the EMC website.

data.question: Board - Contact Info
data.description: Contact info (phone and/or email) for Board Directors is available on the EMC website.

data.question: Board - Demographics
data.description: Board pictures are displayed on the website and they are demographically diverse in terms of age; gender; and racial/ethnic background.

data.question: Board - Diversity Plan
data.description: The EMC has an explicit and appropriate Diversity & Equity plan that includes measures to assess and improve Board representation, develop a pipeline of diverse leadership (Leadership Academy), track the equitable distribution of member benefits, and meet the needs of its most vulnerable customers.

scoresys.value: Have one, but not published online

data.question: Board - Term Limits
data.description: The Board Directors are limited to a total of 6 years or less on the Board in the bylaws or in an EMC policy.

data.question: Bylaws - Amendments
data.description: Bylaws explicitly say member-owners can propose amendments to the bylaws and that all bylaw amendments require a vote by the member-ownership before they can be approved.

scoresys.value: Can propose but there are limits

data.question: Bylaws - Availability
data.description: The bylaws are posted online and are also accessible by other means upon request.

scoresys.value: Online and accessible by other means
Online but not accessible by other means

data.question: Bylaws - Service Territories
data.description: Service territory boundaries are explicitly outlined and publicly available.

data.question: Membership Info Availability to Board Candidates
data.description: Contact info for all members is available upon request, without exception, to qualified Board candidates for use in their election campaign.

data.question: Voting - Accessible
data.description: Member-owners can vote for the Board of Directors in person, online, by early voting, AND by mail.

data.question: Voting - Oversight
data.description: The EMC uses an independent third party to verify the voting results.

data.question: Voting - Member Proxies
data.description: Board Directors should NOT be able to use member proxies to vote.

data.question: Transparency of Financial Information
data.description: 990s and annual financial reports should be posted on the EMC website. (The 990 is the form used by non-profit organizations to file financial information with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) in compliance with tax law. Making these available for review by member-owners is the first step to financial transparency).

data.question: Median Household Income (MHI) for GA Counties Served
data.description: Average of the MHIs for GA Counties Served

data.question: Board Directors
data.description: Number of Board Directors that serve the EMC

data.question: Average Annual Compensation for Board Directors
data.description: Average Annual Compensation for Board Directors. Serving as a Board Director is part-time work.  Most EMCs pay a per diem rate for board work; so Board Directors' annual compensation is the total of those days worked and will vary from Director to Director based on the number of days logged.

data.question: Board Compensation Score (Average Compensation/MHI for Counties Served)
data.description: The average board compensation (given that it is part-time) should be proportionate with average household incomes in the counties served. We measured this by dividing the average pay for Board Members by the average Median Household Income in the counties served. We consider a proportionate Board Compensation to be less than 50% of average MHI.

data.question: Salary of Highest Paid Employee (HPE)
data.description: Salary of Highest Paid Employee (CEO, CFO, COO, President, Form 990, Section VII, Column D)

data.question: HPE - Other Compensation
data.description: HPE - Other Compensation from the Organization and Related Organizations (Form 990, Section 7, Column F)

data.question: HPE - Total Income
data.description: This is a total of the HPE Salary and the HPE Other Compensation (Form 990; Section VII; Column D+Column F)

data.question: Salary of the Highest Paid Employee (HPE) Score (Total Income / MHI for Counties Served)
data.description: The highest paid employee's annual salary should be proportionate to the average MHI in the counties served. We consider proportionate to be less than 5 times the average MHI of the GA counties served. Partial credit is awarded if the HPE Salary is less than 7 times the MHI.

data.question: Capital Credits
data.description: Capital credits are money received by EMC member-owners that represents their individual portion of the co-op's profits. They can be either a direct payment or a credit on their bill. Decisions about whether to return credits should be made annually by the board based on the companys financial condition. If the co-op is in good financial standing credits should be returned annually.

data.question: 901 Year
data.description: Year of 990 used for compensation information

data.question: 901 Link
data.description: Online link for 990

data.question: Emission Reduction Goals
data.description: The EMC has set goal dates to reduce carbon emissions caused by the burning of fossil fuels in its energy portfolio.

data.question: Community Solar
data.description: The EMC offers a cooperative solar program and offers subsidies for low-income participants.

scoresys.value: Has a community solar program + subsidy
Has CSP but no subsidy program

data.question: Distributed Generation Policy
data.description: The EMC's interconnection / distributed generation policy is available online. Distributed generation is when a member-owner generates electricity from their own sources (like solar panels) in addition to or alongside EMC energy resources. Often this means that the solar producer is sometimes selling unused electricity it produces back to the EMC and sometimes buying electricity from the EMC. A distributed generation policy will determine any fees associated with this interconnection and also set the rates at which the EMC will buy electricity from the user.

data.question: Customer Service - Outages
data.description: An online and telephone response system should communicate information and updates about electricity and broadband outages with estimates of restoration times.

data.question: Energy Efficiency Financing
data.description: The EMC should have programs to help finance energy efficiency updates, such as an inclusive Pay As You Save (PAYS) program, a regular loan-based on-bill program, rebates).

scoresys.value: PAYS + rebates and/or regular on-based bill program
Rebates and/or regular on-bill loan-based program

data.question: Humane Disconnection Policy
data.description: The EMC should have a humane disconnection policy that includes payment plan options, temperature limits, medical exceptions, and non-excessive reconnect fees (for example there should not be fees for *both* disconnection and reconnection).

data.question: Fixed Fee Burden
data.description: The monthly fixed fee ('basic facilities or customer charge') charged to residential member-owners should be less than $15/month and should be shown as a separate line item on the bill.

scoresys.value: Less than $15 and shown as separate line item

data.question: Broadband Internet Access
data.description: The EMC should offer broadband internet service to all customers currently unserved in its territory, or it should be actively developing such service, or have applied for a federal grant to begin such development.

data.question: Pesticide Spraying Opt-Out
data.description: Member-owners should be able to opt out of EMC pesticide spraying through a Right-of-Way policy.

data.question: Medical Priority Registration
data.description: The EMC website should instruct member-owners how to register for medical priority status. This status would make their households a priority for electricity restoration in the case of outages in order to keep medical equipment functioning.

data.question: Member Communications
data.description: The EMC distributes a quarterly newsletter with information on member benefits, scholarships, programs, education, and energy efficiency advice.

scoresys.value: Less often or with partial information

data.cta1: Hire an independent agency to conduct annual board elections
data.cta2: Remove all stipulations and prerequisites and allow member-owners to attend monthly board meetings without prior consent or notice. Co-op principals two and five dictate "democratic member control" and "education, training, and information". Open monthly meetings are a must for member-owners to be knowledgeable about what is happening in their co-ops and to participate. This must be clearly stated in the by-laws.
data.cta3: Remove all stipulations and prerequisites and allow member-owners to attend and speak at monthly board meetings without prior consent or notice.

data.cta1: Ensure the board of directors' pictures are available on the EMC website and educate member-owners on running for the board so diverse candidates will participate. This will assist in achieving board representation that is reflective of the demographics of the service territory population.
data.cta2: Update the EMC website to provide the email address and phone number for all board members so member-owners can contact them with questions or concerns.
data.cta3: Hire an independent agency to conduct annual board elections

data.cta1: Ensure the board of directors' pictures are available on the EMC website and educate member-owners on running for the board so diverse candidates will participate. This will assist in achieving board representation that is reflective of the demographics of the service territory population.
data.cta2: Create and distribute a diversity plan that outlines the co-ops targets and standards regarding diversity, equity, and inclusion in the EMC's workforce, leadership, programs/policies, and communications/outreach.
data.cta3: Review and decrease the portion of the fee that is associated with the co-op dues.

data.cta1: Remove all stipulations and prerequisites and allow member-owners to attend monthly board meetings without prior consent or notice. data.cta2: Adopt the policy to provide member-owner information (not to include acct. number) to qualified board of directors election candidates upon request and without exception.
data.cta3: Develop a program and/or apply for grants to provide broadband service for any portion of the EMC service territory that is underserved.

data.cta1: Provide board meeting dates; times; locations; and agenda on the EMC website. This information should be publicly available seeing as the directors are meeting to conduct official business on behalf of member-owners. Moreover, the expectation is that the info is necessary so member-owners know when and where to attend.
data.cta2: Post minutes from monthly meetings on the EMC website within 48 hours. It is imperative that member-owners are privy to the decisions and discussions regarding the EMC. The service territory is expansive and providing meeting notes in a timely manner allow for transparency and accountability throughout the entire territory.
